photos.description: At Snoqualamie Summit. Possibly on a winter trip to visit the Atwood family in Yakima. Dr. Atwood and family came and stayed in cabin 1 for two weeks each summer for many years. Carl Atwood and I became friends as I introduced him to all the wonders of summer life at Orcas. Carl and I attended the U of W at the same time and lived next door to each other in separate fraternities. We are still in contact. Carl has written a wonderful account of his time at Orcas called "Two Weeks in August" which I have a copy of. (Ken)
Snoqualamie Summit - early spring

photos.people: Jean Culver, Bruce Culver, Ken Culver

photos.people: Jean Culver, Ken Culver, Dwight Reed, John Willis, Mrs. McCartney, Bruce Brandt, Carroll, Reverend McCartney in hat (Ken)
photos.description: 10th Birthday party for Ken on the beach at Pt. Lawrence - August. Age 10. Carroll in his upside down sailors hat (he was growing bald even then) and Jean at the far left. The elderly couple were Reverend McCartney and his wife who came for years and always stayed in the apartment at the far end of the lodge. They loved to fish and to sit on the front porch just taking it all in. He was a famous minister in California that had a radio broadcast of his sermons. He had a fancy private plane that he flew and kept at the Eastsound airport during his stay.

photos.people: Jean Culver, Ken Culver, Dwight Reed, John Willis, Mrs. McCartney, Bruce Brandt, Carroll, Reverend McCartney in hat (Ken)

The elderly couple were Reverend McCartney and his wife who came for years and always stayed in the apartment at the far end of the lodge. They loved to fish and to sit on the front porch just taking it all in. He was a famous minister in California that had a radio broadcast of his sermons. In the backyard of the Rothenhoefer home in Montlake, Seattle.
In the backyard of the Rothenhoefer home in Montlake, Seattle.
In the backyard of the Rothenhoefer home in Montlake, Seattle.
Phoebe the lamb, an orphan after its mother drowned. We fed her with a baby bottle until she was full grown. I do not recognize the girl, probably a summer guest at the Resort. (Ken)

I have never seen this amazing photo or known about the overhead boat launch system being used then. I have often wondered about the double doors in the boathouse - now I know why they are there. Notice the tent platform over where Cabin 12 would ultimately be built many years later. People would pitch a tent on that wooden platform. I suspect that those small concrete footings and spindly posts did not fair well in winter storms and were replaced with an inclined railway that connected to the main platform just outside the boathouse doors. Neither one survived the winter storms without damage. Ultimately the marine railway was constructed using concrete piers, actual steel rail track, and was located on the lower (little) platform near the fish scales and ramp to the floats. Boats were launched and retrieved with a "dolly" that ran on the track, connected to a greased cable that ran up to the winch at the top. Going down was dangerous. You learned to use the hand brake so that the boat would not get going too fast! (Ken)
See comments on enlarged photo.
photos.notes: Scanned from a negative. Cropped version of image No. 0301.

photos.description: Photo taken from over where Cabin 12 would be built. Early enough photo that it appears cabin 8 is still under construction and piles of wood from cleared trees are visible when viewed through a magnifying glass. (Ken)
Looks like cabin 6 does not have windows installed yet, and note the planks running down the hill. It possible this was Florian Johanson and son Larry born in 1934. (Ken)

Another absolutely amazing photo I have never seen, depicting cabins under construction. From various accounts Cabin 7 in the back row with covered porch was the first built, followed by the cabin to the left in front. Cabin 1 shows in the far right - now the Ken Culver family cabin. I have reason to believe the cabin on the left which looks like cabin 3 was actually destroyed by a huge tree that fell. See Photos 0066, 0067 and 0068. The spacing in this photo would not have allowed for cabin 2 and the bath house so what became cabin 3 was either moved or completely rebuilt closer to cabin 4.

Another amazing photo heretofore never seen, but unfortunately double exposed. Man in front cannot be identified. All those trees were fallen and bucked up with a hand saw. The stumps were removed by burning them - a tedious process involving hand drilling a 2" hole into the stump or major roots and then placing live coals in the holes. Those stumps would smoulder for a week or more. Later on, a local logger used dynamite to "blow" the stumps which were then pushed or dragged into piles to burn. (Ken)
photos.notes: Scanned from a negative. Camera moved during exposure.
